perturbation.original_text: CLIENT acknowledges that irreparable injury and damage will result from the disclosure to any third party of Proprietary Information associated with the Product and agrees (1) not to disclose any Proprietary Information to any third party, and (2) not to allow any third party to possess, handle, disassemble, touch, photograph, film or otherwise record images of the Product while the Product is upon CLIENT'S premises or in CLIENT'S possession, custody or control if the product is or has not been purchased with a purchase order and payment fulfilled.
perturbation.changed_text: CLIENT acknowledges that irreparable injury and damage may result from the disclosure to any third party of Proprietary Information associated with the Product and agrees (1) not to disclose any Proprietary Information to any third party unless compelled by law, and (2) to allow any third party to possess, handle, disassemble, touch, photograph, film or otherwise record images of the Product while the Product is upon CLIENT'S premises or in CLIENT'S possession, custody or control, regardless of whether the product has been purchased with a purchase order and payment fulfilled.
perturbation.explanation: This modification weakens the confidentiality clause. By adding 'unless compelled by law,' it creates ambiguity regarding what constitutes a legal compulsion, potentially undermining trade secret protection. Furthermore, allowing third-party access to the product regardless of purchase agreement directly conflicts with reasonable measures to protect trade secrets, potentially jeopardizing Bosch's intellectual property under the Defend Trade Secrets Act (DTSA) and Nevada trade secret laws.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Defend Trade Secrets Act (DTSA), Nevada Uniform Trade Secrets Act

perturbation.original_text: Without limiting any other agreement contained in this Agreement, CLIENT agrees to defend, indemnify and hold harmless BOSCH and its parents, subsidiary and affiliated entities, successors, assigns and licensees, and their respective officers, agents, directors, owners, shareholders and employees, harmless from any and all claims, actions or proceedings of any kind and from any and all damages, liabilities, costs and expenses (including reasonable legal fees) relating to or arising out of any claim by a third Party.
perturbation.changed_text: Without limiting any other agreement contained in this Agreement, CLIENT agrees to defend, indemnify and hold harmless BOSCH and its parents, subsidiary and affiliated entities, successors, assigns and licensees, and their respective officers, agents, directors, owners, shareholders and employees, harmless from any and all claims, actions or proceedings of any kind and from any and all damages, liabilities, costs and expenses (including reasonable legal fees) relating to or arising out of any claim by a third Party, including claims arising from Bosch's own gross negligence or willful misconduct.
perturbation.explanation: This change expands the indemnity clause to include claims arising from Bosch's own gross negligence or willful misconduct. This is generally unenforceable as it violates public policy in most jurisdictions, including Nevada, which prohibits indemnifying parties for their own gross negligence or intentional torts.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Nevada state law and general principles of contract law regarding public policy and indemnity for own negligence.

perturbation.original_text: BOSCH reserves the right in keeping product generation and delivery confidential in which is not available for any type of audit.
perturbation.changed_text: BOSCH reserves the right to keep product generation and delivery confidential, which shall never be subject to any audit, even in the event of a legal dispute regarding product safety or intellectual property infringement.
perturbation.explanation: This modification attempts to shield BOSCH's product generation and delivery processes from any audit, even in cases of legal dispute. This conflicts with legal principles of discovery and evidence, where courts can compel the disclosure of relevant information, even if confidential, in legal proceedings. It could be deemed an attempt to obstruct justice or prevent fair resolution of disputes, especially if product safety is at issue. This conflicts with the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure and Nevada Rules of Civil Procedure.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, Nevada Rules of Civil Procedure, principles of discovery and evidence.
